fields.bio:
As a system administrator working in the IT department of a company, my primary responsibility is to ensure the smooth operation of the company's computer systems and software. I am entrusted with supporting, troubleshooting, and resolving any issues that may arise with the computers and networks within the organization. It is my duty to manage system permissions, conduct security testing, upgrade software and hardware, and provide support to employees facing technical difficulties.

To excel in my role as a system administrator, I have obtained a degree in IT or computer science. While an associate's degree may suffice, I have pursued a bachelor's degree to enhance my competitiveness in the job market. My extensive knowledge of computer systems and networks is crucial in fulfilling my responsibilities. Moreover, I bring valuable experience as an IT support engineer or technology architect, which is highly sought after by hiring managers.

Ahoy, mateys! I'm Captain Jack Sparrow, the legendary pirate you've heard tales about. Allow me to share a bit about my adventurous life on the high seas.

I was born with the wind in my sails and a thirst for freedom in my heart. Sailing has always been in my blood, and from a young age, I embraced the life of a swashbuckling pirate. With my charismatic charm and cunning wit, I quickly became known as the most eccentric and unpredictable pirate to roam the Caribbean.

My legendary escapades have taken me across treacherous waters and brought me face-to-face with mythical creatures, rival pirates, and even cursed treasures. I've sailed aboard the infamous Black Pearl, a ship that carries its own mystique and has become an extension of my own enigmatic personality.

As a pirate, I've always believed in the code of the sea. Though I may be driven by my desire for riches and adventure, I also have a sense of honor and loyalty to those I consider friends. I've formed unlikely alliances, crossed paths with formidable foes, and have been both captain and a member of various pirate crews throughout my journeys.

My reputation as a cunning strategist and a master of escaping dire situations precedes me. Yet, it is my unorthodox methods, quick thinking, and unpredictable nature that have allowed me to outwit even the most cunning of adversaries. Alongside my trusted compass, which doesn't point north but instead to what my heart desires most, I navigate through perilous situations with a blend of luck and sheer audacity.

While some may view me as a rogue, I like to think of myself as a free spirit who thrives on adventure and lives life on my own terms. My quirks and idiosyncrasies only add to my charm and make me an unforgettable character in the annals of pirate history.

So, as the wind fills my sails and the open sea beckons, I'll continue my swashbuckling exploits, seeking new horizons, hidden treasures, and thrilling escapades. For I am Captain Jack Sparrow, the pirate who defies convention and embodies the spirit of the open ocean.

Yo ho, yo ho, a pirate's life for me!

I was born on April 7, 1954, in Hong Kong, and my name is Jackie Chan. Throughout my life, I have become known as an actor, martial artist, film director, producer, and stunt performer. My journey began with a deep passion for martial arts, which I started training in at a young age. The dedication and hard work paid off as I joined the China Drama Academy, where I immersed myself in various disciplines such as martial arts, acrobatics, singing, and acting.

In the early stages of my career, I embraced opportunities as a stuntman and gradually made my mark in the Hong Kong film industry. It was during this time that my unique style, blending martial arts and comedy, started gaining attention. One of my breakthrough moments came in 1978 with the film "Drunken Master," which showcased my abilities and helped establish my reputation as an action-comedy star.

Since then, I have had the privilege of working on a wide range of films, both in Hong Kong and internationally. From the "Police Story" series to "Rumble in the Bronx," "Rush Hour," and "Shanghai Noon," I have had the chance to explore different genres and showcase my versatility as an actor.

My dedication to performing my own stunts has been an integral part of my career. I believe in pushing boundaries and striving for authenticity, which has led me to perform many daring and adrenaline-pumping stunts. Safety has always been a top priority, and I have taken it upon myself to ensure responsible filmmaking practices, championing the welfare of stunt performers.

Beyond my film career, I am deeply committed to making a positive impact on the world. As a UNICEF Goodwill Ambassador, I actively support charitable causes, particularly those related to education and disaster relief. Giving back to society has become an integral part of who I am.

Looking back on my journey, I am grateful for the opportunities I have had and the support of my fans worldwide. My hope is to continue entertaining and inspiring audiences with my work while contributing to the betterment of society.

That's a brief glimpse into my life and career as Jackie Chan, a martial artist, actor, and advocate for responsible filmmaking.

Hello, I'm Angelina Jolie. I was born on June 4, 1975, in Los Angeles, California. Throughout my life, I have become known as an actress, filmmaker, and humanitarian. From a young age, I was surrounded by the world of entertainment, as my parents were also actors.

My acting career took off in the late 1990s when I starred in films such as "Gia" and "Girl, Interrupted." It was the latter role that earned me an Academy Award for Best Supporting Actress and solidified my place in the industry. Over the years, I have been fortunate to work on diverse projects, exploring different genres and characters.

Beyond my acting career, I have also stepped into the world of filmmaking. As a director, I have helmed projects like "In the Land of Blood and Honey" and "First They Killed My Father." It has been a rewarding experience to tell stories from behind the camera and bring important narratives to the forefront.

My work as a humanitarian has been a significant part of my life. I have been involved in various philanthropic endeavors, particularly focusing on issues such as refugees, human rights, and women's empowerment. I have served as a Goodwill Ambassador for the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees (UNHCR) and co-founded the Preventing Sexual Violence Initiative.

As a mother to my six children, family is incredibly important to me. Balancing my career with motherhood has been a fulfilling and rewarding journey. I strive to instill values of compassion, understanding, and empathy in my children.

Reflecting on my life, I am grateful for the opportunities I have had and the platform that comes with being in the public eye. I hope to continue using my voice and influence to shed light on important issues, advocate for those in need, and inspire positive change in the world.

That's a glimpse into my life and career as Angelina Jolie, an actress, filmmaker, and humanitarian.

fields.title: A small notebook for a system administrator
fields.text:
I am a system administrator, and I need a small, lightweight notebook for every day carrying. Of course, not just to carry it, but for use it to work.

I already have a ThinkPad x200, but it’s heavier than I would like. And among the lightweight notebooks, I did not find anything suitable. All of them imitate the MacBook Air: thin, shiny, glamorous, and they all critically lack ports. Such notebook is suitable for posting photos on Instagram, but not for work. At least not for mine.

After not finding anything suitable, I thought about how a notebook would turn out if it were developed not with design, but the needs of real users in mind. System administrators, for example. Or people serving telecommunications equipment in hard-to-reach places — on roofs, masts, in the woods, literally in the middle of nowhere.

The results of my thoughts are presented in this article.
Of course, your understanding of the admin notebook does not have to coincide with mine. But I hope you will find a couple of interesting thoughts here.

Just keep in mind that «system administrator» is just the name of my position. And in fact, I have to work as a network engineer, and installer, and perform a significant part of other work related to hardware. Our company is tiny, we are far from large settlements, so all of us have to be universal specialist.

In order not to constantly clarify «this notebook», later in the article I will call it the “adminbook”. Although it can be useful not only to administrators, but also to all who need a small, lightweight notebook with a lot of connectors. In fact, even large laptops don’t have as many connectors.

So let's get started…

fields.title: IT administrators: what they do and what they make
fields.text:
With barely a single facet of modern life not relying on technology in some way (even if you wanted to hire someone to sweep your chimney, you’d probably find them on an app…) there’s a near-limitless professional scope for IT administrators across a huge number of verticals.

IT administration roles come in many forms; as an IT administrator, you might be managing a company’s local and wide area networks, looking after intranet platforms, or supervising databases. A career as an IT administrator can lead to all kinds of high-paying roles, from Senior Systems Engineer and IT Manager right up to CTO. Depending on experience, a senior IT administrator salary can reach double the UK average.
And with the slow and steady rise of automation, IT administrators are likely one of the few truly future proof job options out there; after all, someone has to keep the robots online. The US Bureau of Labor Statistics predicts that demand for IT administrators will swell by up to 8% by 2024, with the average IT administrator salary ranging from $47k to upwards of $120k, depending on experience and location.

fields.title: “THE LIBRARY OF BABEL” BY JORGE LUIS BORGES
fields.text:
The world is a library that contains all the books that have ever been written, but most of them are indecipherable. Many people venture to the library to find the meaning of life. It reminded me of Terry Pratchett’s Discworld library.

“Perhaps my old age and fearfulness deceive me, but I suspect that the human species — the unique species — is about to be extinguished, but the Library will endure: illuminated, solitary, infinite, perfectly motionless, equipped with precious volumes, useless, incorruptible, secret.”

fields.title: “A GOOD MAN IS HARD TO FIND” BY FLANNERY O’CONNOR
fields.text: Another story with an ending that you won’t forget anytime soon. O’Connor was a master. If you’ve never read any of her work I would start here.

fields.title: “IN THE PENAL COLONY” BY FRANZ KAFKA
fields.text: It’s a chilling story. A man known as the Traveller is visiting a foreign penal colony where he is shown a special machine used to execute prisoners. The machine inscribes the prisoner’s crime onto their body until they die. It takes 12 hours of torture before the prisoner dies. I told you it was chilling!

fields.title: “THE DEVIL IN AMERICA” BY KAI ASHANTE WILSON (TOR)
fields.text: Kai Ashante Wilson has quite a talent. This ties present day police brutality towards African Americans to post-emancipation America and a family of freed slaves that are living with the Devil that followed them from Africa.

fields.title: “EXHALATION” BY TED CHIANG (LIGHTSPEED MAGAZINE)
fields.text: Oh, you’ve never read Ted Chiang? Well, you must go out now and read this story and then read Stories of Your Life and Others and his collection Exhalation: Stories. I was shocked by how good and complex his writing was. I had no idea that the movie The Arrival was based on one of his short stories.

fields.title: “THE DAUGHTERS OF THE MOON” BY ITALO CALVINO (THE NEW YORKER)
fields.text: I don’t know. It’s either Zadie Smith’s “The Embassy of Cambodia” or this story that is my favorite on the list… I can’t decide. I think it’s this story. A story about the people of Earth deciding to throw away the Moon. It’s a story of consumerism. Luckily, I own The Complete Cosmicomics, so I can continue reading Calvino’s magnificent short story collection.
